title: 2E - 6HBr - mL of H2- EIO formula- lattice energy

content.question: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. While investigating the chemical and physical properties of metallic element <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a student conducts an experiment by combining <math alttext="E, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H B r, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HBr</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, which react according to the following equation. <math alttext="2 E, solid, plus 6 H B r, aqueous, react to produce 2 E B r 3, aqueous, plus 3 H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2 E</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> + 6 HBr</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext></mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>2 E</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext></mrow><mtext>+ 3</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Write the net-ionic equation for the reaction.

frqParts.text: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. While investigating the chemical and physical properties of metallic element <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a student conducts an experiment by combining <math alttext="E, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H B r, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HBr</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, which react according to the following equation. <math alttext="2 E, solid, plus 6 H B r, aqueous, react to produce 2 E B r 3, aqueous, plus 3 H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2 E</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> + 6 HBr</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext></mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>2 E</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext></mrow><mtext>+ 3</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) Write the net-ionic equation for the reaction.

(b) In the reaction, is <math alttext="E, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> being oxidized or reduced? Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.

As shown in the following diagram, <math alttext="10.00 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.00</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> samples of <math alttext="H B r, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HBr</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are added to different quantities of <math alttext="E, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in a closed test tube. At the start of each trial, the gas-collecting tube is filled completely with distilled water. The samples of <math alttext="E, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> react with <math alttext="H B r, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HBr</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> produced is collected in the gas-collecting tube. (c) The enlarged view of the gas-collecting tube at the end of trial 3 is shown in the diagram above. What should the student record as the volume, in <math alttext="milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, of <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> collected in trial 3?

(d) In the laboratory, the temperature is <math alttext="295 Kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>295</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the total pressure in the gas-collecting tube is <math alttext="744.7 millimeters of H g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>744.7</mn><mtext> mmHg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the vapor pressure of water at <math alttext="295 Kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>295</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="19.8 millimeters of H g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19.8</mn><mtext> mmHg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, determine the pressure of the <math alttext="H 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the gas-collecting tube.

Trial Initial Moles of <math alttext="E, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> Initial <math alttext="molar concentration of H B r, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>HBr</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) Volume of <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> Produced (<math alttext="in milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) 1 <math alttext="5.40 times 10 to the negative 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.40</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.400 19.95 2 <math alttext="6.90 times 10 to the negative 4 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.90</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.400 25.52 3 <math alttext="8.20 times 10 to the negative 4 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8.20</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> 0.400 ? (e) The data from all three trials are given above. A student claims that <math alttext="E, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is the limiting reactant in trial 2. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer with information in the data table.

(f) A certain pure compound containing element <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is analyzed. The elemental composition of the compound is shown in the following table. Determine the empirical formula of the compound using the information in the table. Element Moles Present in the Compound E 0.0167 I 0.050 O 0.200

(g) A different element, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is located in the same column of the periodic table as element <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, but <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has roughly double the atomic mass of <math alttext="E." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the atomic radius of <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> less than, equal to, or greater than the atomic radius of <math alttext="E?" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer using principles of atomic structure.

(h) The ionic radii of ions <math alttext="X with a negative 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Z with a negative 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the following table. Element <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can bond with <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to form <math alttext="E 2 X 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="E 2 Z 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. If lattice energy is defined as the energy required to separate an ionic solid into individual separate gaseous ions, would the lattice energy of <math alttext="E 2 X 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be less than, equal to, or greater than the lattice energy of <math alttext="E 2 Z 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer in terms of Coulomb’s law. Element Ionic radius (<math alttext="in picometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) <math alttext="X with a negative 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> 120 <math alttext="Z with a negative 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> 180

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
